title: comp-text
body:
The Information Security Compliance Training experience provides employees with the fundamental skills & knowledge to protect confidential company & client information from potential cybersecurity breaches.

Employees will be empowered with the awareness to safeguard organizational security through an understanding of information security policies.

Watch the following video to learn more!

title: comp-text
body:
These individuals are a part of a thriving cybercrime industry, which can pose a significant security issue.

However, our biggest security vulnerability is often our employees themselves. This is not due to malicious intent but from a lack of knowledge and understanding around information security.

As you progress through this eLearning module, you will gain the necessary knowledge and skills to safeguard against a variety of cybersecurity threats.

_items.title: Organized Criminals
_items.body: Who collaboratively plan, coordinate, and conduct criminal acts.

_items.title: Hackers
_items.body: Who use various types of technology to gain unauthorized access to confidential data.

_transcript.inlineTranscriptBody:
Sonron Engineering is responsible for the handling and protection of sensitive data for global companies and clientele. As such, our brand reputation and continued success depends on their confidence in us as trustworthy custodians.

Failing to uphold our commitment could result in the:

  • Compromise of critical client information and interruption of services.
  • Loss of trust & reputational damage towards the Sonron brand.
  • Imposition of punitive costs to compensate for security breaches and regulatory penalties.

This means we consider information protection a serious commitment. Our cybersecurity policies include:

  • Sophisticated software systems to protect technology assets.
  • Robust security procedures to handle client data.
  • Global IT security department that defends against malicious attacks.

But our strongest line of defense is YOU.

_items.title: CovidLock Ransomware
_items.body:
In 2020, rising fear around COVID-19 was exploited by cybercriminals.

The CovidLock ransomware infected victims with malicious files under the guise of offering further information about the coronavirus.

_items.title: Business Disruption
_items.body:
Once installed, CovidLock would encrypt data and deny access to the system.

Criminals would then request a monetary ransom to restore the data or else it would be held hostage indefinitely.

_items.title: Malware Impacts
_items.body:
Malware has the ability to:

  • Disrupt business services & workflow productivity.
  • Compromise information security to allow criminal acts.
  • Destroy reputation & trust with Sonron clients.

_items.title: Sonron Responsibility
_items.body:
Sonron has a responsibility to prevent malware and virus infections because of our key relationships with global clients.

Your role requires personal due diligence and vigilance when dealing with possible vulnerabilities like, emails, devices, and web usage.

_items.title: Spelling Mistakes
_items.body: Spelling mistakes, such as, misspelt names or URL links that are oddly formatted, should raise concerns.

_items.title: Appropriate Asks
_items.body:
An inappropriate request, includes, IT asking for your password (as they should be able to obtain this information by themselves) or a upper management asking for a transaction to be processed against normal procedures.

Additionally, a sender might ask for, or provide, something you don't normally deal with, such as, a purchase order or refund.

_items.title: Behaviour & Mannerisms
_items.body:
Is the sender behaving differently compared to previous communications?

They might be using different language or colloquialisms and even ask odd questions.

_items.title: If in Doubt, Report!
_items.body:
If at any point you have doubts, immediately report the communications to your IT security contact.

You should not attempt to:

  • Reply
  • Click Links
  • Download Attachments

_items.title: A Security Incident is...
_items.body:
• Loss of a work-related device, like a laptop or USB drive.
  • Unauthorized access resulting in a data breach.
  • Compromise of sensitive information, such as, your login credentials to an outside party.

_items.title: Who Should I Contact?
_items.body:
Client related matters require you to immediately connect with your project manager, who will notify our IT security and Risk Management teams.

Non-client related issues require you to report to your IT security contact, who will determine next steps.

_items.title: Reporting Duty
_items.body:
Always report information breaches as soon as possible.

This ensures that the appropriate actions are taken to minimize or prevent the damage.

title: comp-mc
displayTitle: Q1. What are common examples of malicious parties that participate in cybercrime?

_items.text: Organized Criminals, Hackers, and State-sponsored Groups.
Organized Criminals, Sonron Employees, and Mechanics.
_items.feedback:
Incorrect.

While, Sonron employees might be the cause of security vulnerabilities, they, and mechanics, would not be considered a "common example of malicious parties".

_items.text: Hackers, State-sponsored Groups, and Non-profit Organizations.
_items.feedback:
Incorrect.

While, non-profit organizations could act as fronts for cybercrime. They would not be considered a "common example of malicious parties".

_items.text: Hackers, Software Engineers, and Sonron Employees.
_items.feedback:
Incorrect.

While, Sonron employees might be the cause of security vulnerabilities, they, and software engineers, would not be considered a "common example of malicious parties".

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Organized criminals, hackers, and state-sponsored groups are considered common participants of cybercrime.

title: comp-text
body:
• Understand the necessity of cybersecurity practices within the workplace and your responsibility in supporting information protection policies.
  • Define information protection measures and their importance to organizational security.
  • Identify techniques used by cybercriminals and their associated prevention measures.
  • Recognize the need to protect confidential information entrusted to the company.
  • Demonstrate proper security procedures for data breaches or security incidents.

Check out the Sonron IT Security homepage for further cybersecurity information!

title: comp-mc
displayTitle: Q2. What is not a possible business impact of a malware infection?

_items.feedback:
Incorrect.

Malware can impact the business through disruption of services.

Incorrect.

Malware can impact the business by enabling fraud.

Incorrect.

Malware can impact the business by destroying reputations and causing a loss of client trust.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

While, malware breaches can be referred to as infections. It is not a biological virus like the common cold.

_bands.feedback:
{{{score}}} out of {{{maxScore}}} at {{{scoreAsPercent}}}%

Congrats! You've passed the assessment!

{{{score}}} out of {{{maxScore}}} at {{{scoreAsPercent}}}%

Looks like you need to review the learning content. Retake the knowledge quiz when you're ready!

title: comp-mc
displayTitle: Q4. As you enter a client facility, an individual approaches and asks if you’d be able to let them in as they’ve lost their ID pass. What should you do?

_items.text: Berate them for suggesting this as it is a possible security issue.
_items.feedback:
Incorrect.

While, letting an individual into a secure facility is a security issue. It would be inappropriate to be rude or combative as you are representing the Sonron brand.

_items.text: Ignore them as you do not know if they are an employee of Sonron or the client.
_items.feedback:
Incorrect.

Although, you may feel suspicious of the individual and not wish to inadvertently assist with a security breach.

It is also possible that they are in need of honest help and ignoring them could reflect badly upon our relationship with the client. Instead guide them to the appropriate assistance services.

_items.text: Assist them as it’s a good idea to help others in need.
_items.feedback:
Incorrect.

You do not know if the individual is operating in good faith as they could be a party with malicious intentions.

_items.text: Politely refuse and offer to escort them over to the reception desk for assistance.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

You should acknowledge the individual's request for help and assist them through the appropriate security services. You should never put yourself in harm's way nor inadvertently assist in security breaches.

title: Q5. Select the appropriate reporting action for each scenario.
displayTitle: Q5. Select the appropriate reporting action for each scenario.

_items.text: Helped a stranger access your apartment building after they forgot their security pass.

_options.text: Report to the appropriate non-Sonron authority or service.

_items.text: Misplaced a USB drive with work-related data.

_options.text: Report to the appropriate non-Sonron authority or service.

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Good job!

You've selected the correct action for each scenario!

_incorrect.final:
Better luck next time!

Try to consider what situations would be relevant to and within the capability of Sonron to resolve.

title: Q3. Which image depicts the social engineering technique of phishing?
displayTitle: Q3. Which image depicts the social engineering technique of phishing?

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Correct!

This image is an example of a phishing email as it shows a falsified email sent by someone attempting to obtain Sonron login credentials.

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect.

This image would better represent shoulder surfing as it shows a person secretively attempting to look at another individual's computer screen.

title: comp-text
body:
You are now ready to complete the Knowledge Quiz! You will be assessed on the previous learning content.

A score of 80% or higher is required to pass. Good luck!

title: mc-practice-scenario
body: How should you respond? Choose the appropriate response below.

_items.text: You decide to ignore them and quickly enter the building. If you pretend to not have seen them, you can avoid having to deal with the confrontation.
_items.feedback:
Oops!

It turns out that the individual was indeed a client employee.

They felt rebuked by your obvious avoidance and ended up voicing their complaints to colleagues.

Although, you prevented a possible security breach through your course of action. It also ended up unnecessarily damaging Sonron’s relationship with the client.

_items.text: You graciously exclaim, “No worries, I’m heading in anyways! Happy to help a colleague in need.”
_items.feedback:
Uh Oh!

A day later, you find out that a major security breach has occurred resulting in critical damage to a refinery.

The facility’s security cameras have captured you assisting the, now malicious, individual with entry. As such, you are suspected of acting as an accessory and could face possible legal charges.

_items.text: You dismissively reply, “Sorry, it’s against company policy to allow entry into secure areas without a pass. Besides, I don’t know if you’re actually an employee here anyways.”
_items.feedback:
Oops!

It turns out that the individual was indeed a client employee.

They felt rebuked by your dismissive attitude and lodged a complaint with their Human Resources department.

Although, you prevented a possible security breach through your course of action. It also ended up damaging Sonron’s relationship with the client as you were unnecessarily accusatory towards the employee.

_items.text: You politely respond, “Sorry, I’d love to help but I'm a guest here so I don’t want to overstep. I’m happy to accompany you to Reception to see what they can do though.”

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
Good Job!

You escorted the individual to the reception desk. Although, you were unable to identify whether or not the person was a malicious actor.

You responded appropriately by following security protocols and maintaining a respectful relationship with our client and their employees.

_items.body: • Politely refuse requests to help gain access. Instead, suggest alternative solutions, like offering to escort them to the reception desk for assistance.
• Feel empowered to question suspicious individuals in a polite and helpful manner. If they don’t respond appropriately, raise your worries to the security team.
• Remember that you are also a guest when operating at client facilities and should expect to be challenged. If this occurs, be respectful and considerate with your responses.
Use these helpful points whenever you find yourself in possible security breach scenario!
